Incident Investigation
The North District WWTP investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in injury to personnel, injury to the public, damage to the environment, or property damage so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team will be assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are evaluated, and appropriate recommendations are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and used as needed to revise operating and maintenance procedures.

Five-Year Accident History Summary
No reportable releases/accidents have occurred at the North District plant during the last 5 years.

Emergency Response Program Summary
The MDWASD emergency response policy involves the preparation and maintenance of emergency response plans for hazardous materials, which are tailored to each facility, and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program Requirements.  North District WWTP has an Emergency Response Plan and Emergency Action Plan, that staff are trained on and MDWASD coordinates emergency planning with offsite response officials. Training is on-going.

All North District WWTP employees are trained as first responders.   Additionally, all employees have been trained in the hazards of chlorine, and the MDWASD Emergency Action Plan.  Employees working with the chlorine process are HAZWOP

ER technician level trained, and receive Process Safety Management training, including training on SOPs, chlorine process safety features, and preventative maintenance procedures.  Management has been trained in Process Safety Management and the regulatory requirements of the Risk Management Planning and Process Safety Management rules.  

Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external resources such as the Miami-Dade County Hazardous Material Team may be solicited to aid in handling chorine.  As part of the emergency response program, the North District WWTP has developed and implemented an emergency action plan and emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting employee safety, the publicÂ¿s health, and the environment.

The emergency response plan has been coordinated with local response agencies (Fire Department, Miami-Dade Department of Emergency Management and Homeland Security).  The main elements of the emergency response plan are: (1) chlorine release response flow chart, responsibilities of various personnel at the facility, duties of on-scene incident commander, site response team, and site safety representative, (2) details of emergency recognition and prevention at the facility, (3) procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations, and (4) details of the training program for all employees involved with the chlorination processes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
Numerous changes to improve safety were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1997 for chlorination and system equipment and procedures, when Process Safety Management (PSM) Plans were prepared.  All of these recommended actions were evaluated for implementation as required. MDWASD is currently in the process of evaluating and implementing recommendations from the March 18, 2009 PHA.  

MDWASD is committed to providing a safe and healthful work environment to its employees, while protecting the public, on-site and off-si
te property, and the environment from releases of chlorine.

Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting treated wastewater.  The Miami-Dade Water and Sewer Department (MDWASD) North District Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) also uses chlorine (for chlorination) for disinfecting treated wastewater for in-plant reuse and on-site irrigation.

Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations.  The North District WWTP takes safety obligations in storing and using all chemicals seriously.

The North District WWTP chlorine handling processes is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule.  This rule requires submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and an update to the RMP every five (5) years.  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the chlorine process, including a description of the possible consequences if the procedures are not followed, and the actions which will be taken by the facility in an event of a chlorine release.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The MDWASD accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates proven chlorine process technology and safety systems, incorporates staff training, provides detailed information on the hazards of chlorine and process safety management, implements operation and maintenance standard operating procedures, trains and plans for emergency response and emergency actions, includes contractor safety, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  

General Facility

and Regulated Substance information
The MDWASD North District WWTP is located at 2575 NE 156 Street, in North Miami, Florida. North District WWTP is bounded by Sunny Isles Boulevard on the north, the Oleta River on the east, NE 151 Street to the south, and Biscayne Boulevard (US1) to the west. The treatment plant has a rated capacity of 112 million gallons per day (mgd). The facility stores chlorine which is a regulated toxic substance under RMP rule.


Chlorine is delivered in one-ton containers to the North District WWTP chlorine building.  The chlorine building is divided into a enclosed chlorine storage room and a chlorination room.  The one-ton containers contain liquid chlorine under pressure.  The chlorine building is equipped to store up to 16 (containers) tons of chlorine.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the North District WWTP at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantity in the RMP rule. It also exceeds the listed threshold quantity in Process Safety Management Standard.

The pressure from the stored chlorine in the cylinder forces liquid chlorine through the tubing and into the manifold system. During normal operation liquid chlorine flows from the cylinder through the chlorine pipeline to the evaporators located in the chlorinator room.  At the evaporators, the liquid chlorine is heated and converted into chlorine gas.  The evaporators are equipped with high and low temperature alarms, to ensure that normal temperature is maintained. Chlorine gas then flows from the evaporators through the temperature-actuated control valve to the chlorinators.  The chlorinators are used to control the feed rate of the chlorine gas.  The chlorinators are equipped with a gas Rotometer and v-notched orifice for controlling the feed rate.  Injection of the chlorine into the process water produces the concentrated chlorine solution that flows through Iron piping to the various injection points in the treatment process.

The North District WWTP chlori

ne systems are provided with a number of safety features to protect the employees and the surrounding community.  Safety features include, but are not limited to automatic emergency shut-off valves, chlorine leak detectors, audio and visual alarm system, isolation valves, high and low temperature alarms, high and low pressure alarms, pressure regulators, expansion tanks, bursting disks, and pressure relief valves.  Chlorine Kit Â¿BÂ¿ and personal protective equipment, including self-contained breathing apparatus are available in the event of a chlorine release.  These major safety features are located in the chlorine storage area and in the chlorinator room.

Automatic emergency shut-off valves are located immediately after located immediately downstream of the manifold system.  Pushing one of the emergency shut-off switches (kill switches) activates the emergency shut-off valves.  The emergency shut-off switches are located at the chlorine storage area and in the chlorinator room.  The automatic shut-off valves can also be activated automatically by the chlorine leak detection system sensing chlorine at a concentration greater than 1.0 ppm.  Additional manually-operated isolation valves are located throughout the chlorine system.

The leak detection and alarm system in the chlorine storage area and chlorinator room is activated when chlorine gas is sensed.  The leak detection system is set to activate the alarms when a chlorine concentration of 1.0 ppm or higher is detected.  When the leak detection system detects a leak, audio and visual alarms are activated.  When the chlorine alarms are engaged, personnel are restricted from entering the chlorine area without the appropriate personnel protective equipment.  

A perimeter fence and locked security gates surround the North District WWTP. Security guards are posted at the entrances to the plant and at the chlorine storage area, and unauthorized access is not allowed.  The Plant operates with three shifts of employe

es onsite 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

The North District WWTP is also provided with a backup emergency power generator that supplies power to the entire facility.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The North District WWTP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
Â¿	Detailed management system.	
Â¿	Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
Â¿	 Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
Â¿	Performance of process hazard analysis (PHA) of covered processes, with operation and maintenance staff participation and review, and trained PHA facilitator.
Â¿	 Use of the-state-of-the art process and safety equipment and documentation of equipment safety information.
Â¿	Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operations and maintenance personnel, and safety staff.
Â¿	Training of the all facility personnel, including management, operators and maintenance staff, security and all workers at the plant site.
Â¿	Implementation of an incident investigation program.
Â¿	Chemical-specific prevention steps including the  availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine,  presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and remotely controlled shutoff devices on the chlorine storage tanks.
Â¿	Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine. This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets, along with process and chemical safety information.
Â¿	Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provide in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe uppe

r and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility. 


Process Hazard Analysis
In 1997, a detailed Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs) was conducted of the chlorine system process, including safety features, procedures, and maintenance.  The PHA was updated again in 2001 and a list of recommended actions was developed to further improve safety.  An additional PHA was conducted in 2009 and recommendations are in the process of being evaluated and/or implemented.

Operating procedures 
MDWASD North District WWTP has prepared written operating procedures that provide clear instruction and steps for safely conducting activities relating to the chlorination processes.  Written Standard Operating Procedures include: startup, normal operation, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, start-up after emergency shutdown, receipt of chlorine, and chlorine cylinder change.  All SOPs have been recently reviewed and updated.

Training
North District WWTP employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine processes are trained in the chlorine process and the applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  North District WWTP ensures that each employee newly assigned to the chlorine process, is trained and tested to be competent in the process safety management, standard operating procedures, consequences of deviation from the SOPs, and chlorine process safety features.   Each employee involved in operating the chlorine system, has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities, including emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.

Management Personnel are trained on Process Safety Management and compliance with Federal and State Regulations pertaining to Risk Management Planning and Process Safety Management.  All on-site facility personnel that are not involved directly with the chlorine system are also

trained in the MDWASD Emergency Action Plan, and the hazards of chlorine.

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures. 

The North District WWTP prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training and provides certification of the records, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training. 

Contractors
MDWASD North District WWTP has procedures and policies in place that specify the information required to be provided to the contractors performing work on the chlorination processes, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules.  MDWASD North District WWTP is required to provide information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes and obtain and evaluate information regarding the contractorÂ¿s safety program.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program
North District WWTP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting up a new covered process or after a shutdown event, or prior to starting up modifications to the chlorination processes that require a MOC procedure implementation.

Hot Work Permits and Management Change
The North District WWTP requires that employees and contractors employ safe work practices when performing hot work in, on, or around the covered process.  The North District WWTP uses a permitting program to ensure that hot work is conducted safely on, or near a process involving chlorine.
